bioghist.head: Content Description
bioghist.p: Hudiakoff was born in Trubchevsk, a small town in western Russia.

The youngest child in a large peasant and worker's family, Andrei was a child when he reportedly found an old tin can with some white oil paint in it which he used to make different colors using brick dust, laundry blueing, stove soot in order to paint his first picture. The child artist attracted the attention of a Russian nobleman who sent him to art school in Moscow. He was earning his way through the Moscow School of Fine Arts when the Revolution broke out, and he left Russia.

After a long series of adventures, he became a designer of scenery and costumes in Berlin, and in the early twenties, a Broadway producer, Morris Gest, brought him to the United States. Here he married an American girl, and established his home in New York.
Hudiakotf continued his theater work, and designed and painted innumerable murals. For a year he attended the National Academy of Design in New York and won a silver medal for life studies.
He and his wife, Doris Geile, established themselves in Newtown, CT and became patrons of the Booth Library. Hudiakoff's work was at times exhibited at the Booth Library in Newtown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials in the small collection were acquired to supplement the original art pieces also in possession of the WCSU Archives in the Marjorie Echols Collection.
